I told John Kerry that it is time to stop misrepresenting our view on the South China Sea dispute.
http://www.khmertimeskh.com/news/21723/chinese-warships-dock-in-sihanoukville/ "five days of naval exercises with the Cambodian navy" expected. It seems that this local coverage (@morrell) is rather boastful of the exercises. In that I am only following this situation as part of the GJ activity, I've learned something from this article. Previously I thought the "issue" was the United States seeking to pressure the ASEANs to not cooperate with the Chinese as to naval exercises, as some show of anti-Chinese-expansion solidarity. I've learned that this perspective may be too simplistic, for the article frames the South Sea tension in terms of China versus not the U.S., but versus Japan! If this is true, then whoever came up with this (failed) U.S. strategy of "blackballing" the Chinese from naval exercises needs their head examined. It has completely backfired: the U.S. did not achieve ASEAN solidarity, an important ally (Japan) is also besmirched, and Cambodia rises in prominence in the so-called "consensus-led" ASEAN. If Japan were smart they would have distanced themselves from this "plan" before it began. If the U.S. wants to get serious in the South China Sea, even though they're so far behind the ball timewise, they need to escalate those faux-islands to the top international priority, skip the rhetoric that they want "free navigation," and move directly to the declaration that any militarization of those faux-islands will be destroyed. China has fourteen days to remove any and all weapons or the U.S. just vaporizes them. Whatever "strategy" the U.S. is now undertaking is something, maybe, that was suitable before the first ton of sand was dredged to create those faux-islands. Once their construction began, only a hard-and-fast rule with a credible response was required. It's not too late to reverse the current (failed) policy that now not only fails to address the central issue of faux-islands, but is bringing down U.S. and ally policy alike in the entire region; and driving the ASEAN nations toward China, rather than empowering them (as Cambodia desires) to stand on their own. I give Cambodia (if sincere) a ton of credit for calling out the United States for having the audacity to frame the U.S.-Cambodia relationship in terms of China (or Japan).

The anticipated exercise with Cambodia notwithstanding, I am uncertain as to why the recent Indian Fleet Review did not resolve this question. As is evident from the cited article, "stressing ... cooperation" and "deterrence by presence" were aspects "complementing the exercise." As you know, if there was something that we could base an objective determination of "just what a naval exercise is," I'd be the first to argue for that. But, when we do not have such a standard, and the usage employed by the actors does not violate common sense or basic logic, or reveal an intention to deceive, I'm not sure what the reason would be to not just go along with the actors interpretation of events. Here, an independent host country (India) is calling an activity that both China and Malaysia participated in, a [naval] exercise. I see no reason to dispute that claim. The objective of "cooperation" seems as good as any other for the purpose of a naval exercise.

How dare Cambodia not do the bidding of the United States! Let's accuse them of doing China's bidding! [Attention Political Science PhDs: the topic of "consensus" in international bodies desperately requires immediate attention. There's a whole bunch of sinister and unaccountable crap being jammed in under this rubric, not least of which is that consensus-centric organizations seem more susceptible to outside and imbalanced influences. One must be wary of words with good connotations turned bad. "Consensus" is a dangerous word.]

Hedging Game The tribunal decision will also likely have repercussions for the ability of ASEAN members to unite in addressing the issue. This could further erode the credibility of ASEAN centrality, a concept that requires members to be united, given that full consensus is needed to achieve any result under the various ASEAN mechanisms. The majority of ASEAN members wish to maximize trade and investment ties with Beijing while maintaining a close security relationship with Washington. However, members countries have a range of positions when it comes to the Sino-U.S. rivalry. These positions can be broadly placed into one of three groups. Most of the claimants, but most notably the Philippines and Vietnam, have been highly critical of China. The Philippines has elected to renew the Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement with the U.S., despite domestic criticism on the question of sovereignty and expanding content. This decision was motivated by anxiety at China’s growing assertiveness in the South China Sea. As for Vietnam, although an alliance remains out of reach given resistance from hardline elements, relations with the U.S. are increasingly warm, and China is a factor in this. A second group of ASEAN members, notably Indonesia, Singapore, and Thailand, have been very keen to maintain strategic autonomy. Nevertheless, with a massive influx of Chinese investment, countries such as Indonesia that are in dire need of infrastructure have been struggling to preserve their neutrality. After work started on Indonesia’s first ever high-speed rail link, a controversial Chinese project that will connect Jakarta and Bandung, Indonesia announced another megaproject that will be led by a Chinese state-owned electricity company. Although the Indonesian government has attempted to preserve its neutrality, for instance declining Beijing’s invitation to conduct military drills in the South China Sea late last year, the country is clearly drawing closer to China. The third group includes Cambodia, Myanmar, and Laos (CML), all countries determined to avoid any position that puts them directly at odds with China. Many observers concluded that Cambodia’s failure in 2012 to agree on a communiqué owed to its decision not to corner its most important economic partner. The gaps between these already divergent positions are only likely to widen after ITLOS announces its decision, with a new round of friction likely. This will motivate claimants to step up their efforts to reassert their claims and to bolster security ties with external powers, especially the U.S. and Japan. Claimants such as Vietnam, depending on the outcome of the Philippines’ case, may start their own legal processes. Members will also pressure various ASEAN meetings to address the challenges that China’s claims present. This will put the non-claimants in the difficult position of having to choose between their fellow ASEAN members and China.

Chinese leadership views their nation from a long historical perspective of many centuries.  This world view results in a future where China "rightfully" returns to a dominant, if not the ultimate, power in the world.  They are building a world class navy, which they are. and will continue to use, as a major tool of military and economic power, influence and control.  They are now 'executing' military  basing agreements around the world, the most recent and telling is a naval outpost in Djibouti (Horn of Africa).  Their leadership especially views the ocean areas off their coast as "rightfully" an area of their control.  They are now demonstrating this world view by building/creating small island military bases on what were reefs, and declaring to the world that most of the South China Sea is their area of of control and are attempting to enforce these claims with their Navy and Peoples Liberation Army Air Force.  For economic and political reasons, at least one or more SE Asian country will agree to conduct naval exercises with China.  SE Asian countries, like many "allies" of the US, now feel that China is now the strong horse in this area, and maybe all over the world, since the US demonstrated in many ways that we no longer wants to be a 'super power.'
I do not believe this would be in the interest of any ASEAN nation, and even if they were to wish so, the U.S. would discourage them from participating.

I can imagine Singapore Indonesia Malaysia having anti piracy drills with the Chinese but everyone else sees them as the bully in asean. Vietnam Philippines Taiwan would be opposed so a navy drill partner would consider trading repercussions.

v. con·duct·ed, con·duct·ing, con·ducts
v.tr.
1. To direct the course of; manage or control: a police officer who conducts traffic; a scientist who conducts experiments.
2. To lead or guide: conducted the tourists through the museum.
3. Music To direct the performance of (an orchestra or chorus, for example).
4. To serve as a medium for conveying; transmit: Some metals conduct heat.
5. To comport (oneself) in a specified way: The students conducted themselves with dignity throughout the ceremony.
v.intr.
1. To act as a director or conductor.
2. To show the way; lead.
n. (kŏn′dŭkt′)
1. The way a person acts, especially from the standpoint of morality and ethics.
2. The act of directing or controlling; management.
3. Obsolete A guide; an escort.

According to the DOD's annual report on China's military, the following are all the bilateral/multilateral military exercises involving China and an ASEAN state since 2008:  - 2008: Strike 2008 (Counterterrorism), Thailand - 2009: Cooperation 2009 (Counterterrorism), Singapore
- 2009: Unnamed (Maritime), Singapore
- 2009: Aman (Peace) 2009 (Maritime), several ASEAN members - 2010: Blue Strike/Blue Assault 2010 (Counterterrorism), Thailand
- 2010: Cooperation 2010 (Counterterrorism), Singapore
- 2010: Strike 2010 (Counterterrorism), Thailand
- 2010: Unnamed (Search and Rescue), Vietnam - 2011: Sharp Knife-2011 (Counterterrorism), Indonesia
- 2011: Unnamed (Maritime), Vietnam
- 2011: Aman (Peace) 2011 (Maritime), several ASEAN members - 2012: Blue Assault 2012 (Maritime), Thailand
- 2012: Sharp Knife 2012 (Counterterrorism), Indonesia
- 2012: Unnamed (S&R), Vietnam - 2013: ADMM+ Exercise in Brunei 2013 (Maritime, S&R), ASEAN
- 2013: Shark Knife 2013 (Counterterrorism), Indonesia
- 2013: Strike 2013 (Counterterrorism), Thailand - 2014: Sharp Knife 2014 (Counterterrorism), Indonesia
- 2014: Komodo (Naval Diplomacy), Indonesia
- 2014: RIMPAC (Naval Exercise), several ASEAN members
- 2014: Group Sail (Maritime), Singapore & Brunei
- 2014: Cobra Gold (HA/DR), Thailand
- 2014: Cooperation 2014 (Infantry), Singapore - 2015: Aman (Peace) 2015 (Maritime), several ASEAN members Link to DOD report (see p. 77 for list of exercises involving China): http://www.defense.gov/Portals/1/Documents/pubs/2015_China_Military_Power_Report.pdf
